title: Solutions Activity 2: Boxplots
text:
These are the solutions to Activity 2: Boxplots. You should try that one first.
Boxplots are another common way of displaying numeric data. Let’s continue our exploration of births14. I’ve loaded the libraries below for you.
We’re going to be using the boxplot function type ?gf_boxplot() into the console or a new chunk to get a sense of the argument this function takes.
Recall where we left off with Activity 1.

favstats(weight~sex,data=births14)

     sex  min    Q1 median    Q3   max     mean       sd   n missing
1 female 0.75 6.435   7.19 7.785  9.68 7.017253 1.271234 495       0
2   male 1.12 6.690   7.44 8.240 10.62 7.375485 1.318031 505       0


The mosaic package is nice, because all of the functions have very similar setups.

Make a boxplot with the function gf_boxplot(). Copy and past the arguments from the favstats function above (don’t copy the favstats part).


gf_boxplot(weight~sex,data=births14)





Notice all of the outliers! We don’t know how to remove them yet, but we will later. We can pretend they are not there by adjusting the coef argument. Set coef=5. Do that in the chunk below.


gf_boxplot(weight~sex,data=births14,coef = 5)




If you remember the formula for calculating outliers (Q1-1.5 *IQR, Q3+1.5 * IQR), this is the formula R uses by default. coef = 5 changes the 1.5 to 5.

Put the outliers back and figure out how to change their shape and stroke. Just like with histograms we can add change the x and y labels and add a title. Add the chunk below and change the outliers shape.


gf_boxplot(weight~sex,data=births14,outlier.shape = 3,outlier.stroke = 2, xlab="Child's Birth Sex",ylab="Birthweight In Pounds",title = "Babies Weigh A Little When Born")





Can you map the color (or fill) argument to the smoking habit of the mother, so we can see three variables at once?


gf_boxplot(weight~sex,data=births14, fill=~habit, xlab="Child's Birth Sex",ylab="Birthweight In Pounds",title = "New Born Babies' Weight By Mother's Smoking Habit")




I promise when we get to Day 3 we’ll talk about removing outliers. We have to use the filter function.

title: Descriptive statistics
text:
How to Follow Along.
 Open this presentation in a new browser tab. You can copy and paste code from there.

Work in the console.

We’ll discuss other methods (.rmd, .qmd, scripts) of working in R later.

title: Descriptive statistics
text: Lets talk about counties

title: Descriptive statistics
text:
Load the libraries
library(openintro)

This is where the data lives

library(mosaic)

This is where (most of) our statistical functions live

library(tidyverse)

This is where the view() function lives

title: Descriptive statistics
text:
Explore the data frame
Try the following in the console.


view(x = county)
names(county)
dim(county)
?county

title: Descriptive statistics
text:
The ? operator
The ? will bring up the help tab.
Try


?county
?mosaic
?mean()

title: Descriptive statistics
text:
Measures of center


mean()

mean(~pop2017,data=county, na.rm=TRUE)

median()

Find the median population from 2017

mode()

title: Descriptive statistics
text:
Measures of Spread


IQR(~pop2017,data=county, na.rm=TRUE)
sd()

title: Descriptive statistics
text:
All summary stats()


fivenum()
favstats(~pop2017,data=county, na.rm=TRUE)1
quartile()


favstats() is the friendliest and the one we use the most

title: Descriptive statistics
section: Get specific details on each state
text:
Get specific details on each state
Find the mean population for all 50 states.
mean(pop2017~state,data=county)

library(mosaic)

title: Histograms and Boxplots
text:
Histograms and Boxplots
Let’s consider the county data frame.

county

# A tibble: 3,142 × 15
   name    state pop2000 pop2010 pop2017 pop_c…¹ poverty homeo…² multi…³ unemp…⁴
   <chr>   <fct>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <int>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>
 1 Autaug… Alab…   43671   54571   55504    1.48    13.7    77.5     7.2    3.86
 2 Baldwi… Alab…  140415  182265  212628    9.19    11.8    76.7    22.6    3.99
 3 Barbou… Alab…   29038   27457   25270   -6.22    27.2    68      11.1    5.9 
 4 Bibb C… Alab…   20826   22915   22668    0.73    15.2    82.9     6.6    4.39
 5 Blount… Alab…   51024   57322   58013    0.68    15.6    82       3.7    4.02
 6 Bulloc… Alab…   11714   10914   10309   -2.28    28.5    76.9     9.9    4.93
 7 Butler… Alab…   21399   20947   19825   -2.69    24.4    69      13.7    5.49
 8 Calhou… Alab…  112249  118572  114728   -1.51    18.6    70.7    14.3    4.93

title: Histograms and Boxplots
text:
A simple histogram
Map the unemployment rate for the counties in the US in 2019.

gf_histogram(~unemployment_rate,data = county)

title: Histograms and Boxplots
text:
Function’s arguments
Every function in R can take a lot of arguments. Let’s type  ?gf_histogram to see the arguments for that function.



object = NULL,
binwidth,
linetype,
subtitle,


gformula = NULL,
alpha = 0.5,
size,
caption,


data = NULL,
color,
xlab,
geom = “bar”,


…,
fill,
ylab,
stat = “bin”,


bins = 25,
group,
title,
position = “stack”,

title: Histograms and Boxplots
text:
Make a pretty histogram
Start with the single variable histogram: gf_histogram(~unemployment_rate,data = county,...) and add some arguments.


Edit the bins or binwidth, which get priority?
Edit color and fill. Which tints what? (Hint colors are in quotes, color=“pink” works) Here’s a list of colors
Add a title and caption. Remove the label from the x-axis add a good one to the y.
What the heck do size, linetype, and group do?

title: Histograms and Boxplots
section: Here’s a graph that I made
text:
Here’s a graph that I made

gf_histogram(~unemployment_rate,data=county,bins=10, color="black",fill="purple", xlab="",ylab="Number of unemployed", title="US Umeployment by county", caption="Data is as of 2019",linetype = 5,size=2)

title: Histograms and Boxplots
text:
Show two variables
The histogram is a single variable graph by we can break up the data by grouping it.

gf_histogram(~unemployment_rate,data=county,bins=10, fill = ~metro)

title: Histograms and Boxplots
text:
Two variables (faceted):
Let’s make two histograms side by side.

gf_histogram(~unemployment_rate|~metro,data = county)

title: LAB ACTIVITY: R Workshop Day 1
text:
There is a data frame called penguins inside a package called palmerpenguins. In the console, you can use the view() function to open this data frame in a new tab.
Please insert code chunks below each question.
Use the names() function to list all the variables in this data.

PART 1. CATEGORICAL VARIABLES
In your view(penguins) tab, see that there are two categorical variables: species and island.
SPECIES
Use the tally() function to count how many penguins of each species are in this data.
Let’s make visualizations of the above table.
Use gf_counts() to make a bar plot of the different species. Use color and fill commands to make it more visually appealing!
Use the mosaic() function to make a mosaic plot of the species variable.
ISLAND
Use the tally() function to find out the penguin count on each island for this data set. BE CAREFUL! Do not click “islands” suggestion! That is the name of different data set that RStudio is recognizing!
Let’s make visualizations of the above table.
Use gf_props() to make a bar plot of the island variable. Use color and fill commands to make it more visually appealing!
Use the mosaic() function to make a mosaic plot of the island variable.
SPECIES ON EACH ISLAND
Use the tally() function to count the number of each different species on each of the different islands. (This is a 2-by-2 contingency table!)



Intepret the values in the above table. Which species/island combination is most represented in this data? In words, what do the zeros mean?
Let’s make visualizations of the above table.
Use gf_percents() to make a bar plot of the different species and the fill = to color each bar according the island variable. This allow us to see for each species, how many came from each island.
Use the mosaic() function to make one mosaic plot of the species and island variables together.
For an extra challenge, let’s try adding color.
Use the highlighting argument to specify a variable to highlight with variable name in quotes.
For example, highlighting = “species”.
Use the highlighting_fill argument to specify your colors. In this case, three colors are needed.
For example, highlighting_fill = c(“color1”, “color2”, “color3”) Insert your color names inside quotes!


PART 2. ONE NUMERICAL VARIABLE, ONE CATEGORICAL VARIABLE
Recall from class how we made comparative side-by-side boxplots using the county data. We did this by taking the numerical variable of poverty rates (called poverty) separating the poverty rates into two groups based on the “yes or no” levels of the categorical variable metro. Recall that metro was “yes” if county has a large urban metro area) or “no” (county does not have a large urban metro area.)
The code we used for this is given below:

gf_boxplot(poverty ~ metro, data = county)




Use this same idea to make comparative side-by-side boxplots of the numerical variable called body_mass_g which gives the weight of the penguins in grams.
Which penguin species has the largest median weight? Did any species have outliers? Which species has the smallest IQR (DO you remember how to see IQR in a boxplot?) Do any species data show skew? Symmetric?
Use the same technique above with favstats() to find all the major summary statistics of body_mass_g for all three species using just one line of code! Be careful of the order of the variables! What happens if you reverse them? (Notice in the output that there is missing data.)
Use the same technique above to compute IQR for each species. Again, be careful of the order of the variables!You need to use an argument to remove missing data.
Which species has the least variability in the middle 50%? Does this agree with what you saw in the side-by-side boxplots?
Make a histogram of body mass faceted by species and also colored by species.


PART 3. TWO NUMERICAL VARIABLES - SCATTERPLOTS AND CORRELATION.
It seems plausible that, regardless of species, penguins with larger body mass could also have longer flippers and a longer bill. Let’s make scatterplots for each of these variables to examine their relationship with body mass. And from the graphs, we will consider which of these two variables seems to be more highly correlated with body mass.
First, make a scatterplot with bill length on the y-axis, body mass on the x-axis. (Make sure you get the correct variable names! Use the names() function or go look at the data frame! And remember y-axis variable goes first inside the function as y ~ x). Be sure to include the straight trend line to your plot with *geom_lm().
Next, make a scatterplot with flipper length on the y-axis, body mass on the x-axis. Be sure to include the straight trend line to your plot with *geom_lm().
From these two scatterplots, do you see a linear relationship? You should! Does bill length or flipper length appear to be more highly correlated with body mass or do they look about the same? In other words, do the points appear more closely clustered around the straight line in one of the scatterplots?
Let’s dig deeper into this question by finding the value of the correlation statistic. There is missing data so include the command use = “complete”
Compute the Correlation statistic for bill length and body mass.
Compute the Correlation statistic for flipper length and body mass.


PART 4. FUN CHALLENGE!

MULTIVARIABLE SCATTERPLOT
Choose one of the scatterplots above and try to map as many variables as you can to the plot. Can you get 6 of the 8 variables onto the plot?



PART 5. OPTIONAL HOMEWORK!

1) Finish the activity above if you have not done so already.


AND/OR


2) Repeat some of the same analyses on a different data frame as decribed below.
In the mdsr package, there is a data frame called HELPrct. The HELP study was a clinical trial for adult inpatients recruited from a detoxification unit. In the console, type ?HELPrct to learn more.
Use categorical variables substance, homeless, sex and numerical variables cesd (measure of depressive symptoms, higher scores indicate more symptoms) and mcs (mental component score, higher scores indicate better functioning). Experiment with tally, bar plots, mosaic plots, scatterplots of cesd and mcs, correlation, etc.

title: NOTEBOOK: Workshop Day 1
text:
Categorical Variables

Contingency Tables
The tally function counts the levels of a categorical variable. For the loans_full_schema data frame, count the levels of the homeownership variable.



Count all combinations of homeownership and application_type.



Add row/column totals using margin argument.





Bar Plots
Create bar plot of a categorical variable with counts on the y-axis.



Proportions on the y-axis.



Percents on the y-axis.



Two Categorical variable Stacked Bar Plot.



Side-By-Side Stacked Bar Plot.





Mosaic Plots



Scatterplots
We start with the Births78 data frame in the mosaicData package. Plot births on the y-axis, date on the x-axis.



Let’s add a color and label the axes and give it a title.



Color the points according to the variable wday.



Facet.



Facet with a mosaic function gf_facet_wrap().



With mtcars, Map as many variables as we can to the plot! In the console, type ?mtcars to learn about the variables.





Correlation
We can add linear and non-linear models to a scatterplot. Let’s plot mpg on the y-axis against drat, hp, wt. mpg ~ drat mpg ~ hp mpg ~ wt
Compute correlations for each of the three cases.

title: Solutions Activity Descriptive Stats
text:
These are some solutions, you should do the activity first.

We should always attempt to understand our data first.

view births14 in the chunk below. You can also use the ? operator to learn more.

view(births14)
births14

# A tibble: 1,000 × 13
    fage  mage mature      weeks premie visits gained weight lowbi…¹ sex   habit
   <int> <dbl> <chr>       <dbl> <chr>   <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl> <chr>   <chr> <chr>
 1    34    34 younger mom    37 full …     14     28   6.96 not low male  nons…
 2    36    31 younger mom    41 full …     12     41   8.86 not low fema… nons…
 3    37    36 mature mom     37 full …     10     28   7.51 not low fema… nons…
 4    NA    16 younger mom    38 full …     NA     29   6.19 not low male  nons…
 5    32    31 younger mom    36 premie     12     48   6.75 not low fema… nons…
 6    32    26 younger mom    39 full …     14     45   6.69 not low fema… nons…
 7    37    36 mature mom     36 premie     10     20   6.13 not low fema… nons…
 8    29    24 younger mom    40 full …     13     65   6.74 not low male  nons…
 9    30    32 younger mom    39 full …     15     25   8.94 not low fema… nons…
10    29    26 younger mom    39 full …     11     22   9.12 not low male  nons…
# … with 990 more rows, 2 more variables: marital <chr>, whitemom <chr>, and
#   abbreviated variable name ¹​lowbirthweight

?births14

The grey rectangles are called code chunks.
To make a new code chunk you can type three tick marks ``` (the tick is above the tab key) and a curly bracket with the letter r in the middle {r}. You end a chunk with three more tick marks, like the chunks above.

Make a chunk below and use favstats() to get an idea of the summary statistics for a baby’s birthweight. You can give it a name after the r like understand-data above. No space allowed in chunk names.


favstats(~weight,data=births14)

  min    Q1 median Q3   max    mean       sd    n missing
 0.75 6.545   7.31  8 10.62 7.19816 1.306775 1000       0



Use favstats() and a formula (use the ~) to break up the weight summary statistics by the sex of the child.


favstats(weight~sex, data=births14)

     sex  min    Q1 median    Q3   max     mean       sd   n missing
1 female 0.75 6.435   7.19 7.785  9.68 7.017253 1.271234 495       0
2   male 1.12 6.690   7.44 8.240 10.62 7.375485 1.318031 505       0



Challenge: Add another variable to your favstats: whether the mother was a smoker or nonsmoker. The formula will be similar to the chunk above but will include a plus sign after the second variable.


favstats(weight~sex + habit , data=births14)

         sex.habit  min     Q1 median     Q3   max     mean       sd   n
1 female.nonsmoker 1.19 6.4850   7.19 7.8100  9.68 7.095724 1.160877 435
2   male.nonsmoker 1.81 6.7775   7.50 8.2875 10.42 7.445231 1.278858 432
3    female.smoker 0.75 5.5000   6.94 7.5800  9.25 6.430377 1.759516  53
4      male.smoker 1.12 6.1100   7.13 7.8900  9.12 6.891639 1.420373  61
  missing
1       0
2       0
3       0
4       0



What happens when you switch the sex and habit variables in the chunk above?

A: The summaries are the same, but is listed differently. For more examples see ?favstats()

favstats(weight~habit + sex , data=births14)

         habit.sex  min     Q1 median     Q3   max     mean       sd   n
1 nonsmoker.female 1.19 6.4850   7.19 7.8100  9.68 7.095724 1.160877 435
2    smoker.female 0.75 5.5000   6.94 7.5800  9.25 6.430377 1.759516  53
3   nonsmoker.male 1.81 6.7775   7.50 8.2875 10.42 7.445231 1.278858 432
4      smoker.male 1.12 6.1100   7.13 7.8900  9.12 6.891639 1.420373  61
  missing
1       0
2       0
3       0
4       0



Can you use the same formulas above for the mean() and IQR() functions?

A: Yes you can!

mean(weight~habit + sex , data=births14)

nonsmoker.female    smoker.female   nonsmoker.male      smoker.male 
        7.095724         6.430377         7.445231         6.891639

title: Workshop information
section: If you can have 5 minutes before the workshop
text:
If you can have 5 minutes before the workshop
You should log onto the RStudio server. The server is on campus, but you can log in remotely.


HCC Faculty:
Log onto the HCC Rstudio server.
HCC faculty your username is your hcc email with the @hcc.edu.
Nic’s is nschwab@hcc.edu
Your password is your hcc email password.



WSU and STCC faculty:
We are working on getting you temporary usernames and passwords for HCC Rstudio Server. Hopefully you’ll get an email from Nic with usernames by the end of the day on Friday the 19.

title: Workshop information
text:
If you like a challenge1:
(or you are a WSU of STCC faculty and are tired of waiting for your server password)
Install R and R Studio then type the following into the console:
install.packages("mosaic")
install.packages("tidyverse")
install.packages("openintro")
note: its not that hard, but you may experience errors that the rest of the group does not get, we’ll help you with those.

title: Confidence Interval and Hypothesis Testing
text:
Functions for Confidence Intervals




These are the functions for confidence intervals.


prop.test(…., correct =FALSE)
t.test()


The same functions are used for hypothesis testing.

title: Confidence Interval and Hypothesis Testing
text:
The Data Sets

We’ll use a couple of different data sets for the different CI and hypothesis tests.

For a proportion we’ll use the exclusive_relationship data set.
For a single mean lets use cars93.
For a difference of Means test we’ll use the Sleep data frame (captial S).

title: Confidence Interval and Hypothesis Testing
text:
Proportions
If we were to run ?proptest we’d find.
x- count of successes, length 2 vector of success and failure counts, a formula, or a character, numeric, or factor vector containing raw data.
n- sample size (successes + failures) or a data frame (for the formula interface).
conf.level- the confidence level must be between 0 and 1.


The “correct” argument is not listed.

title: Confidence Interval and Hypothesis Testing
text:
Confidence Interval for Proportions
What is the 90% Confidence interval for the proportion of students who have been in exactly 4 relationships?

#Assume independence
#At least 10 successes/failures
tally(~num==4, data=exclusive_relationship)

num == 4
 TRUE FALSE  <NA> 
   53   150    15 



prop.test(x= ~num == 4,data=exclusive_relationship, conf.level = 0.90, correct=FALSE)


    1-sample proportions test without continuity correction

data:  exclusive_relationship$num == 4  [with success = TRUE]
X-squared = 46.35, df = 1, p-value = 9.892e-12
alternative hypothesis: true p is not equal to 0.5
90 percent confidence interval:
 0.2137559 0.3146963
sample estimates:
        p 
0.2610837

title: Confidence Interval and Hypothesis Testing
section: What the heck is Continuity Correction?
text:
What the heck is Continuity Correction?
You can use the special $ operator 

results <- prop.test(~num==4,data=exclusive_relationship, conf.level = 0.90, correct=FALSE)
results$conf.int

[1] 0.2137559 0.3146963
attr(,"conf.level")
[1] 0.9


 or you can use the wrapper confint() 

confint(prop.test(~num==4,data=exclusive_relationship, conf.level = 0.90, correct=FALSE))

          p     lower     upper level
1 0.2610837 0.2137559 0.3146963   0.9

title: Confidence Interval and Hypothesis Testing
text:
Make the CI look better?
You can use the $ operator 

results <- prop.test(~num==4,data=exclusive_relationship, conf.level = 0.90, correct=FALSE)
results$conf.int

[1] 0.2137559 0.3146963
attr(,"conf.level")
[1] 0.9


 or you can use the wrapper confint() 

confint(prop.test(~num==4,data=exclusive_relationship, conf.level = 0.90, correct=FALSE))

          p     lower     upper level
1 0.2610837 0.2137559 0.3146963   0.9

title: Confidence Interval and Hypothesis Testing
section: To make the CI look better
text:
To make the CI look better
 You can use the $ operator 

results <- prop.test(x= ~num==4,data=exclusive_relationship, conf.level = 0.90, correct=FALSE)
results$conf.int

[1] 0.2137559 0.3146963
attr(,"conf.level")
[1] 0.9


 or you can use the wrapper confint() 

confint(prop.test(x= ~num==4,data=exclusive_relationship, conf.level = 0.90))

          p     lower     upper level
1 0.2610837 0.2114776 0.3172773   0.9

title: Confidence Interval and Hypothesis Testing
section: You can also make a CI from a homework problem.
text:
You can also make a CI from a homework problem.

A store randomly samples 603 shoppers over the course of a year and finds that 142 of them made their visit because of a coupon they’d received in the mail. Construct a 95% confidence interval for the fraction of all shoppers during the year whose visit was because of a coupon they’d received in the mail.

A sample size n=603 and 142 successes.

confint(prop.test(x=142,n=603,correct=FALSE))

          p     lower    upper level
1 0.2354892 0.2033633 0.270964  0.95

title: Confidence Interval and Hypothesis Testing
text:
A Warning on Proportions
prop.test(... correct= FALSE) is built into mosaic and works well with problems based on the OpenIntroStats text on MyOpenMath made by Adam Gilbert. .
If you are using a different problem set and prop.test() doesn’t work, you should check out binom.test(). .
binom.test(... method="Wald") returns the same values that a TI-83 calculator would produce.

title: Confidence Interval and Hypothesis Testing
text:
Proportion Hypothesis Test
To make a hypothesis we need two more arguments. 

p - This is the population proportion from the null hypothesis
alternative - c(“two.sided”, “less”, “greater”)

\(H_0: p= 0.3\)
\(H_1: p\ne 0.3\)
\(\alpha=0.05\)

prop.test(x=~num==4, p=0.3, alternative="t", data=exclusive_relationship, conf.level = 0.90, correct=FALSE)


    1-sample proportions test without continuity correction

data:  exclusive_relationship$num == 4  [with success = TRUE]
X-squared = 1.464, df = 1, p-value = 0.2263
alternative hypothesis: true p is not equal to 0.3
90 percent confidence interval:
 0.2137559 0.3146963
sample estimates:
        p 
0.2610837

These are the functions for confidence intervals.


prop.test(…., correct =FALSE)
t.test()


The same functions are used for hypothesis testing.

title: Confidence Interval and Hypothesis Testing
text:
The Data Sets

We’ll use a couple of different data sets for the different CI and hypothesis tests.

For a proportion we’ll use the exclusive_relationship data set.
For a single mean lets use cars93.
For a difference of Means test we’ll use the Sleep data frame (captial S).

title: Confidence Interval and Hypothesis Testing
text:
Proportions
If we were to run ?proptest we’d find.
x- count of successes, length 2 vector of success and failure counts, a formula, or a character, numeric, or factor vector containing raw data.
n- sample size (successes + failures) or a data frame (for the formula interface).
conf.level- the confidence level must be between 0 and 1.


The “correct” argument is not listed.

title: Confidence Interval and Hypothesis Testing
text:
Confidence Interval for Proportions
What is the 90% Confidence interval for the proportion of students who have been in exactly 4 relationships?

#Assume independence
#At least 10 successes/failures
tally(~num==4, data=exclusive_relationship)

num == 4
 TRUE FALSE  <NA> 
   53   150    15 



prop.test(x= ~num == 4,data=exclusive_relationship, conf.level = 0.90, correct=FALSE)


    1-sample proportions test without continuity correction

data:  exclusive_relationship$num == 4  [with success = TRUE]
X-squared = 46.35, df = 1, p-value = 9.892e-12
alternative hypothesis: true p is not equal to 0.5
90 percent confidence interval:
 0.2137559 0.3146963
sample estimates:
        p 
0.2610837

title: Confidence Interval and Hypothesis Testing
section: To make the CI look better
text:
To make the CI look better
 You can use the $ operator 

results <- prop.test(x= ~num==4,data=exclusive_relationship, conf.level = 0.90, correct=FALSE)
results$conf.int

[1] 0.2137559 0.3146963
attr(,"conf.level")
[1] 0.9


 or you can use the wrapper confint() 

confint(prop.test(x= ~num==4,data=exclusive_relationship, conf.level = 0.90))

          p     lower     upper level
1 0.2610837 0.2114776 0.3172773   0.9

title: Confidence Interval and Hypothesis Testing
section: You can also make a CI from a homework problem.
text:

A store randomly samples 603 shoppers over the course of a year and finds that 142 of them made their visit because of a coupon they’d received in the mail. Construct a 95% confidence interval for the fraction of all shoppers during the year whose visit was because of a coupon they’d received in the mail.

A sample size n=603 and 142 successes.

confint(prop.test(x=142,n=603,correct=FALSE))

          p     lower    upper level
1 0.2354892 0.2033633 0.270964  0.95

Functions for Confidence Intervals

prop.test(…., correct =FALSE)
t.test()


The same functions are used for hypothesis testing.

text:
The cheat sheets

The mosaic cheat sheet
